Award.AwardTitle: Ultra-Low Power and Ultra-Sensitive Spintronic Nanowire Strain Sensor

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this proposal is to investigate an ultra-low power, miniaturized, spintronic nanowire strain sensing device with an ultra-high sensitivity. This concept leverages two different physical phenomena: (i) stress induced magnetization rotation in nanoscale magnetostrictive materials; and (ii) change in the magneto-resistance of a "spin-valve" heterostructure nanowire consisting of magnetically-hard/spacer/magnetically-soft layers, which is induced by a rotation of the magnetization orientation of the soft layer.

If successful, this could lead to a miniature strain sensor with an active area of 0.1mm x 0.1mm and with a sensitivity exceeding state-of-the-art, while consuming 2-3 orders of magnitude less power. Such a device could strongly impact several areas such as structural health monitoring, pressure, flow, acoustic and seismic sensing. This project will provide a strong multidisciplinary experience and mentorship for PhD students and will be leveraged to enhance innovative workshops on sensing and energy harvesting for high school students through the Math-Science Innovation Center. Under-represented K-12 students will be hosted for a month in summer under VCU's Richmond Area Program for Minorities in Engineering (RAPME) program and trained in nanofabrication under this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this proposal was to investigate spin and charge transport in dielectrophoretically (DEP) assembled single nanowire devices in order to demonstrate an ultra-low power, miniaturized, spintronic nanowire sensing device.

Intellectual Merit: Under this grant, the three investigators’ research groups have carried out a multi-year collaboration to accomplish:

1. Growth of homo- and heterostructured semiconductor and metallic nanowires (~50 nm diameter) and their assembly using dielectrophoresis (DEP) to achieve devices at the scale of a single-nanowire.

2. Spin transport investigation in the nanowire heterostructure "spin-valves" to demonstrate spin relaxation lengths at room temperatures due to carrier confinement in a single subband that suppresses D'yakonov-Perel' spin relaxation.

3. Demonstration of ultra-sensitive sensing devices based on single nanowires; specifically a single nanowire magnetic field sensor and strain sensor.

 

Broader impact: Work performed under this grant has demonstrated a pathway to develop single-nanowire based miniaturized, ultra-low power magnetic field and strain sensors.  This project has resulted in four journal papers and one book chapter, apart from many invited and contributed conference talks. In addition, four PhD thesis have been partly funded on the grant (two of which have been awarded). The PI held one virtual workshop (2015) and one hands-on workshop (2017) on nanomagnetism for high school students. The PI and the co-PIs worked with the Richmond Minorities in Engineering Partnership (RMEP) program to host 2-3 students for a month (4-5 weeks) each in summers of 2014 and 2015. They trained in nanofabrication under this project.
